AFRS 1019
20002
Holy Songs in a Strange Land
 MUS 1011
cHumanities 		TR 10:00-11:25 AM Judith Casselberry TBA
 

  • Associated Term

    Spring 2014

  • Credits

    1.0

  • Separate Lab(s)

    No

  • Originating Department

    Africana Studies

    • Other Class Attributes

    Class Eligibility Rules

    • Permission Required

    • Major/Minor Restriction

    • Class Standing Restrictions

      Must have one of the following Class Standings --

      First Year, First Semester

    • Class Exclusion

    • Prerequisite

    • Co-requisite

    • Equivalent Course(s)

    • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

      First years only

    • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

    • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

      No

    • Course Description

      Examines Black American sacred music from its earliest forms, fashioned by enslaved Africans, through current iterations, produced by Black global actors of a different sort. What does bondage sound like? What does emancipation sound like? Can we hear corresponding sounds generated by artists today? In what ways have creators of sacred music embraced, rejected, and re-envisioned the "strange land" over time? Looks at musical and lyrical content and the context in which various music genres developed, such as Negro spirituals, gospel, and sacred blues. Contemporary artists such as Janelle Monáe, Beyoncé and Lupe Fiasco included as well.

    • Class Comment

    • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
      166100
    • Bowdoin Bookstore
    • Registration Instructions
    AFRS 1103
    20155
    FULL
    Black-White Boogie: African Derived Dances in America
    		 DANC 1103
    ESDExplor Social Differences
    VPAVisual and Performing Arts
    cHumanities     		TR 9:30-11:25 AM Nyama McCarthy-Brown TBA
     

    • Associated Term

      Spring 2014

    • Credits

      1.0

    • Separate Lab(s)

      No

    • Originating Department

      Theater and Dance

      • Other Class Attributes

      Class Eligibility Rules

      • Permission Required

      • Major/Minor Restriction

      • Class Standing Restrictions

      • Class Exclusion

      • Prerequisite

      • Co-requisite

      • Equivalent Course(s)

        DANC 103 From Fall 2012 Through Fall 2012

        AFRS 103 From Fall 2012 Through Fall 2012

      • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

        1-senior majors/minors

        2-senior non-majors/minors and junior majors/minors

        3-junior non-majors/minors

        4-sophomores and first years

      • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

      • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

        No

      • Course Description

        Combines dance history, embodied research, and performance. Students engage in readings, class discussions, and movement studies that allow them to learn movement techniques from past eras. Students explore connections between cultural values and norms and movement aesthetics, and discover how African American vernacular dance and jazz music influenced jazz forms and American dance throughout the twentieth century (ragtime, swing, hot jazz, and hip-hop). Culminates with a performance in the December Dance Concert. Students meet once a week in a seminar setting to investigate one dance era, such as swing. The next two class meetings take place in a dance studio in order to embody the dance form discussed that week, and include rehearsals.

      • Class Comment

      • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
        222200FULL

      • Registration Instructions

        AFRS 2141
        20328
        The History of African Americans from 1865 to the Present
        		 HIST 2141
        ESDExplor Social Differences
        cHumanities         		TR 11:30-12:55 PM Patrick Rael TBA
         

        • Associated Term

          Spring 2014

        • Credits

          1.0

        • Separate Lab(s)

          No

        • Originating Department

          History

          • Other Class Attributes

          Class Eligibility Rules

          • Permission Required

          • Major/Minor Restriction

          • Class Standing Restrictions

          • Class Exclusion

          • Prerequisite

          • Co-requisite

          • Equivalent Course(s)

            HIST 237 From Spring 1996 Through Spring 2011

            AFRS 237 From Spring 1996 Through Spring 2011

          • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

            All equally

          • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

          • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

            Yes

          • Course Description

            Explores the history of African Americans from the end of the Civil War to the present. Issues include the promises and failures of Reconstruction, the Jim Crow era, black leadership and protest institutions, African American cultural styles, industrialization and urbanization, the world wars, the Civil Rights Movement, and conservative retrenchment.

          • Class Comment

          • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests

          • Registration Instructions
          AFRS 2210
          20003
          Beyond Capoeira: History and Politics of Afro-Brazilian Culture
          		 HIST 2871
          LAS 2110
          cHumanities           		TR 2:30-3:55 PM Laura Premack TBA
           

          • Associated Term

            Spring 2014

          • Credits

            1.0

          • Separate Lab(s)

            No

          • Originating Department

            Africana Studies

            • Other Class Attributes

            Class Eligibility Rules

            • Permission Required

            • Major/Minor Restriction

            • Class Standing Restrictions

              Must NOT have one of the following Class Standings --

              First Year, First Semester

            • Class Exclusion

            • Prerequisite

            • Co-requisite

            • Equivalent Course(s)

              HIST 200 From Fall 2012 Through Fall 2012

              LAS 221 From Fall 2012 Through Fall 2012

              AFRS 210 From Fall 2012 Through Fall 2012

            • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

              1-majors/minors

              2-senior non-majors/minors

              3-junior non-majors/minors

              4-sophomores

            • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

            • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

              No

            • Course Description

              Seminar. Brazil has the largest population of African descent outside Africa. Nowadays, Brazilians pride themselves on their country’s unique racial and cultural heritage, but it hasn’t always been this way. For centuries, many Afro-Brazilian practices were illegal. Now, however, we are in the midst of what might be called an Afro-Brazilian renaissance. This is something to be celebrated, but it is also something to be questioned. Do these efforts to delineate, praise, and preserve Afro-Brazilian culture actually limit our understanding of it? Has labeling certain aspects of Brazilian cultural heritage as African created a situation in which other ways that Africa has influenced Brazil are overlooked? Just what do we mean by “African” and “Brazilian” anyhow? Takes a historical and anthropological approach to these and other related questions.

            • Class Comment

            • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
              163130
            • Bowdoin Bookstore
            • Registration Instructions
            AFRS 2235
            20004
            Global Pentecostalism: The Roots and Routes of Twentieth Century Christianity
            		 GWS 2229
            REL 2247
            ESDExplor Social Differences
            IPInternational Perspectives
            cHumanities             		T 6:30-9:25 PM Judith Casselberry TBA
             

            • Associated Term

              Spring 2014

            • Credits

              1.0

            • Separate Lab(s)

              No

            • Originating Department

              Africana Studies

              • Other Class Attributes

                Writing Project Course

              Class Eligibility Rules

              • Permission Required

              • Major/Minor Restriction

              • Class Standing Restrictions

                Must NOT have one of the following Class Standings --

                First Year, First Semester

              • Class Exclusion

              • Prerequisite

              • Co-requisite

              • Equivalent Course(s)

                HIST 274 From Spring 2013 Through Spring 2013

                AFRS 242 From Spring 2013 Through Spring 2013

                LAS 245 From Spring 2013 Through Spring 2013

                REL 247 From Spring 2013 Through Spring 2013

              • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                1-majors/minors

                2-senior non-majors/minors

                3-junior non-majors/minors

                4-sophomores

              • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

              • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                No

              • Course Description

                Seminar. Pentecostalism is a form of Christianity centered on the gifts of the Holy Spirit. Pentecostals speak in tongues, heal, prophesize, see visions, and exorcise demons. By many accounts, Pentecostalism is the fastest-growing religion in the world. While the Pentecostal population is difficult to count, current estimates place the world’s total number of adherents at close to 600 million, of whom 75% are women. With particular attention to its intersections with gender, ethnicity, and class, explores the religion’s appeal; its impact on devotees’ lives; and resultant local, regional, and global implications. Case studies include the Americas, the Caribbean, and Africa.

              • Class Comment

              • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                161240
              • Bowdoin Bookstore
              • Registration Instructions
              AFRS 2236
              20161
              Afro-Modern II: Technique
              		 DANC 2241
              ESDExplor Social Differences
              VPAVisual and Performing Arts
              cHumanities               		TR 1:00-2:25 PM Nyama McCarthy-Brown TBA
               

              • Associated Term

                Spring 2014

              • Credits

                0.5

              • Separate Lab(s)

                No

              • Originating Department

                Theater and Dance

                • Other Class Attributes

                Class Eligibility Rules

                • Permission Required

                • Major/Minor Restriction

                • Class Standing Restrictions

                • Class Exclusion

                • Prerequisite

                • Co-requisite

                • Equivalent Course(s)

                • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                  All equally

                • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                  No

                • Course Description

                  A continuation of modern dance principles introduced in Dance 1211 with the addition of African-derived dance movement. The two dance aesthetics are combined to create a new form. Technique classes will include center floor exercises, movement combinations across the floor, and movement phrases. Students will also attend dance performances in the community.

                  • Course Description

                    Repertory students are required to take Dance 2241 concurrently. A continuation of modern dance principles introduced in Dance 1211 with the addition of African-derived dance movement. The two dance aesthetics are combined to create a new form. Through regular rehearsals students will be a part of an artistic creative process and perform in the Spring Dance concert at the end of the semester.

                  AFRS 2364
                  20332
                  Conquest, Colonialism, and Independence: Africa since 1880
                  		 HIST 2364
                  ESDExplor Social Differences
                  IPInternational Perspectives
                  cHumanities                   		TR 10:00-11:25 AM David Gordon TBA
                   

                  • Associated Term

                    Spring 2014

                  • Credits

                    1.0

                  • Separate Lab(s)

                    No

                  • Originating Department

                    History

                    • Other Class Attributes

                    Class Eligibility Rules

                    • Permission Required

                    • Major/Minor Restriction

                    • Class Standing Restrictions

                    • Class Exclusion

                    • Prerequisite

                    • Co-requisite

                    • Equivalent Course(s)

                      HIST 264 From Spring 2008 Through Spring 2012

                      AFRS 264 From Spring 2008 Through Spring 2012

                    • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                      1-first years

                      2-sophomores

                      3-juniors

                      4-seniors

                    • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                    • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                      Yes

                    • Course Description

                      Focuses on conquest, colonialism, and its legacies in sub-Saharan Africa; the violent process of colonial pacification, examined from European and African perspectives; the different ways of consolidating colonial rule and African resistance to colonial rule, from Maji Maji to Mau Mau; and African nationalism and independence, as experienced by Africa’s nationalist leaders, from Kwame Nkrumah to Jomo Kenyatta, and their critics. Concludes with the limits of independence, mass disenchantment, the rise of the predatory post-colonial state, genocide in the Great Lakes, and the wars of Central Africa.

                    • Class Comment

                    • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                      3521140
                    • Bowdoin Bookstore
                    • Registration Instructions

                      AFRS 2504

                      Nineteenth-Century American Fiction
                      		 ENGL 2504
                      cHumanities                       		MW 11:30-12:55 PM Tess Chakkalakal TBA
                       

                      • Associated Term

                        Spring 2014

                      • Credits

                        1.0

                      • Separate Lab(s)

                        No

                      • Originating Department

                        English

                        • Other Class Attributes

                        Class Eligibility Rules

                        • Permission Required

                        • Major/Minor Restriction

                        • Class Standing Restrictions

                        • Class Exclusion

                        • Prerequisite

                          One of: (ENGL 1000-1049, 1100-1999, 010-030, or 100-199) OR (AFRS 1000-1049, 1100-1999, 010-030, or 100-199)

                        • Co-requisite

                        • Equivalent Course(s)

                        • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                          All equally

                        • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                        • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                          No

                        • Course Description

                          Historical survey of nineteenth-century American fiction, including works by Washington Irving, Catherine Sedgwick, Herman Melville, Nathaniel Hawthorne, Frank Webb, Harriet Beecher Stowe, William Wells Brown, Mark Twain, Frank Norris, Henry James, John DeForest, Edith Wharton, William Dean Howells, and Charles Chesnutt. Note: This course fulfills the literature of the Americas requirement for English majors.

                        • Class Comment

                        • Registration Instructions
                        AFRS 2584
                        20235
                        The Afterlives of Uncle Tom
                        		 ENGL 2584
                        cHumanities                         		MW 2:30-3:55 PM Peter Coviello
                        Tess Chakkalakal                         		TBA
                         

                        • Associated Term

                          Spring 2014

                        • Credits

                          1.0

                        • Separate Lab(s)

                          No

                        • Originating Department

                          English

                          • Other Class Attributes

                          Class Eligibility Rules

                          • Permission Required

                          • Major/Minor Restriction

                          • Class Standing Restrictions

                          • Class Exclusion

                          • Prerequisite

                          • Co-requisite

                          • Equivalent Course(s)

                          • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                            1-first years

                            2-sophomores

                            3-juniors

                            4-seniors

                          • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                          • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                            No

                          • Course Description

                            Considers the intertwined fates of slavery and sentiment in the lead-up to, and the years following, the Civil War. At its center is Harriet Beecher Stowe’s 1852 Uncle Tom’s Cabin. Tracks the ramifying effects of this antebellum mega-bestseller, in such disparate realms as literary and print culture, political counter-publics, and law. Explores in particular how responses to the novel in Southern, British, and African-American literary discourses ring complex changes on the major tropes of Stowe’s novel, and on the received wisdom about Uncle Tom that persists into today. Note: This course fulfills the literature of the Americas requirement for English majors.

                          • Class Comment

                          • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                            4015250
                          • Bowdoin Bookstore
                          • Registration Instructions
                          AFRS 2630
                          20236
                          Staging Blackness
                          		 ENGL 2654
                          cHumanities                           		TR 2:30-3:55 PM Guy Mark Foster TBA
                           

                          • Associated Term

                            Spring 2014

                          • Credits

                            1.0

                          • Separate Lab(s)

                            No

                          • Originating Department

                            English

                            • Other Class Attributes

                            Class Eligibility Rules

                            • Permission Required

                            • Major/Minor Restriction

                            • Class Standing Restrictions

                            • Class Exclusion

                            • Prerequisite

                              ENGL 1000-1049, 1100-1999, 010-030, or 100-199

                            • Co-requisite

                            • Equivalent Course(s)

                              AFRS 263 From Spring 2008 Through Spring 2008

                              ENGL 263 From Spring 2008 Through Spring 2008

                            • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                              1-majors/minors

                              2-senior non-majors/minors

                              3-junior non-majors/minors

                              4-sophomores

                              5-first years

                            • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                            • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                              No

                            • Course Description

                              Examines the history and contributions of African Americans to United States theater from the early blackface minstrel tradition, to the revolutionary theater of the Black Arts writers, to more recent postmodernist stage spectacles. Among other concerns, such works often dramatize the efforts of African Americans to negotiate ongoing tensions between individual needs and group demands that result from historically changing forms of racial marginalization. A particular goal is to highlight what Kimberly Benston has termed the “expressive agency” with which black writers and performers have imbued their theatrical presentations. Potential authors include Zora Neale Hurston, Langston Hughes, Lorraine Hansberry, Amiri Baraka, Ron Milner, Adrienne Kennedy, Ntozake Shange, George C. Wolfe, Anna Deavere Smith, Afro Pomo Homos, and August Wilson.

                            • Class Comment

                            • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                              355300
                            • Bowdoin Bookstore
                            • Registration Instructions
                            AFRS 2841
                            20005
                            History of African and African Diasporic Political Thought
                            		 HIST 2841
                            cHumanities                             		MW 1:00-2:25 PM Olufemi Vaughan TBA
                             

                            • Associated Term

                              Spring 2014

                            • Credits

                              1.0

                            • Separate Lab(s)

                              No

                            • Originating Department

                              Africana Studies

                              • Other Class Attributes

                              Class Eligibility Rules

                              • Permission Required

                              • Major/Minor Restriction

                              • Class Standing Restrictions

                                Must NOT have one of the following Class Standings --

                                First Year, First Semester

                              • Class Exclusion

                              • Prerequisite

                              • Co-requisite

                              • Equivalent Course(s)

                                HIST 216 From Fall 2009 Through Spring 2012

                                AFRS 216 From Fall 2009 Through Spring 2012

                              • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                1-majors/minors and sophomores

                                2-junior/senior non-majors/minors

                              • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                              • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                No

                              • Course Description

                                Seminar. Critically discusses some seminal works in African diaspora and African political thought in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Organized around global and national currents that will allow students to explore intersections in pan-African, African American, and African political thought in the context of Atlantic and global histories. Seminar topics divided into three major historic moments. The first explores major themes on Atlantic slavery and Western thought, notably slavery and racial representation, slavery and capitalism, and slavery and democracy. The second focuses on the struggle of African Americans, Africans, and West Indians for freedom in post-Abolition and colonial contexts. Topics discussed within twentieth-century national, regional, and global currents include reconstruction and industrialization, pan-Africanism, new negro, negritude, colonialism, nationalism. Finally, explores pan-African and African encounters in the context of dominant postcolonial themes, namely decolonization, Cold War, state formation, imperialism, African diaspora feminist thought, and globalism. Discusses these foundational texts and the political thoughts of major African, African American, and Caribbean intellectuals and activists in their appropriate historical context.

                              • Class Comment

                              • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                161060
                              • Bowdoin Bookstore
                              • Registration Instructions
                              AFRS 2901
                              20018
                              Archaeology of the Black Atlantic
                              		 ANTH 2901
                              IPInternational Perspectives
                              bSocial & Behavioral Sciences                               		TR 1:00-2:25 PM Scott MacEachern TBA
                               

                              • Associated Term

                                Spring 2014

                              • Credits

                                1.0

                              • Separate Lab(s)

                                No

                              • Originating Department

                                Sociology and Anthropology

                                • Other Class Attributes

                                Class Eligibility Rules

                                • Permission Required

                                • Major/Minor Restriction

                                • Class Standing Restrictions

                                • Class Exclusion

                                • Prerequisite

                                  One of: ANTH 1101, 1150, 101, or 102

                                • Co-requisite

                                • Equivalent Course(s)

                                • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                  1-senior majors/minors

                                  2-junior majors/minors

                                  3-sophomores

                                  4-everyone else

                                • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                  No

                                • Course Description

                                  Uses archaeology to explore the experience of Africans and their descendants in the Atlantic World from the fifteenth century onward. Examines archaeological sites in Africa, the New World, and the Atlantic islands that are implicated in the trans-Atlantic slave trade and in other forms of interaction between African and non-African communities. Particular topics to be explored will include comparisons between archaeological and historical documentation, archaeological evidence for domination and resistance, and the material traces of cultural contacts and hybridity.

                                • Class Comment

                                • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                  3510250
                                • Bowdoin Bookstore
                                • Registration Instructions
                                AFRS 3011
                                20240
                                African American Film
                                		 ENGL 3011
                                FILM 3011
                                cHumanities                                 		W 1:00-3:55 PM Elizabeth Muther TBA
                                 

                                • Associated Term

                                  Spring 2014

                                • Credits

                                  1.0

                                • Separate Lab(s)

                                  No

                                • Originating Department

                                  English

                                  • Other Class Attributes

                                  Class Eligibility Rules

                                  • Permission Required

                                  • Major/Minor Restriction

                                  • Class Standing Restrictions

                                  • Class Exclusion

                                  • Prerequisite

                                    One of: (ENGL 1000-3999 or 010-399) OR (ARFS 1000-3999 or 010-399) OR (FILM 1000-3999 or 010-399)

                                  • Co-requisite

                                  • Equivalent Course(s)

                                    AFRS 308 From Fall 2012 Through Fall 2012

                                    ENGL 308 From Fall 2012 Through Fall 2012

                                  • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                    1-senior minors

                                    2-junior majors/minors

                                    3-everyone else

                                  • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                  • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                    No

                                  • Course Description

                                    Explores a spectrum of films produced since 1950 that engage African American cultural experience. Topics may include black-white buddy movies, the L.A. Rebellion, blaxploitation, the hood genre, cult classics, comedy and cross-dressing, and romance dramas. Of special interest will be the documentary impulse in contemporary African American film; gender, sexuality, and cultural images; the politics of interpretation—writers, filmmakers, critics, and audiences; and the urban context and the economics of alienation. Extensive readings in film and cultural theory and criticism.

                                  • Class Comment

                                  • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                    161150
                                  • Bowdoin Bookstore
                                  • Registration Instructions
                                  AFRS 3140
                                  20342
                                  Research in Nineteenth-Century United States History
                                  		 HIST 3140
                                  cHumanities                                   		T 6:30-9:25 PM Patrick Rael TBA
                                   

                                  • Associated Term

                                    Spring 2014

                                  • Credits

                                    1.0

                                  • Separate Lab(s)

                                    No

                                  • Originating Department

                                    History

                                    • Other Class Attributes

                                    Class Eligibility Rules

                                    • Permission Required

                                    • Major/Minor Restriction

                                    • Class Standing Restrictions

                                      Must NOT have one of the following Class Standings --

                                      First Year, First Semester

                                    • Class Exclusion

                                    • Prerequisite

                                      HIST 1000-3999 or 010-399

                                    • Co-requisite

                                    • Equivalent Course(s)

                                      HIST 336 From Spring 2000 Through Spring 2011

                                      AFRS 336 From Fall 2001 Through Spring 2011

                                    • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                      1-senior majors/minors

                                      2-junior majors/minors

                                      3-senior non-majors/minors

                                      4-junior non-majors/minors

                                      5-sophomores

                                    • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                    • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                      No

                                    • Course Description

                                      A research course for majors and interested non-majors that culminates in a single 25–30 page research paper. With the professor’s consent, students may choose any topic in Civil War or African American history, broadly defined. This is a special opportunity to delve into Bowdoin’s rich collections of primary historical source documents.

                                    • Class Comment

                                    • Registration Instructions
                                    AFRS 3211
                                    20286
                                    Bringing the Female Maroon to Memory: Female Marronage and Douboutism in French Caribbean Literature
                                    		 FREN 3211
                                    GWS 3211
                                    LAS 3211
                                    cHumanities                                     		TR 1:00-2:25 PM Hanetha Vete-Congolo TBA
                                     

                                    • Associated Term

                                      Spring 2014

                                    • Credits

                                      1.0

                                    • Separate Lab(s)

                                      No

                                    • Originating Department

                                      Romance Languages

                                      • Other Class Attributes

                                      Class Eligibility Rules

                                      • Permission Required

                                      • Major/Minor Restriction

                                      • Class Standing Restrictions

                                      • Class Exclusion

                                      • Prerequisite

                                        Two courses: [(FREN 2407-2411, 3000-3999, 207-211, or 300-399) or (AFRS 2407 or 207) or (LAS 2407 or 206)] AND [(FREN 2407-2411, 3000-3999, 207-211, or 300-399) or (AFRS 2407 or 207) or (LAS 2407 or 206)]

                                      • Co-requisite

                                      • Equivalent Course(s)

                                      • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                        1-senior majors/minors

                                        2-junior majors/minors

                                        3-sophomores

                                        4-junior/senior non-majors/minors

                                        5-first years

                                      • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                      • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                        No

                                      • Course Description

                                        History has retained the names of great male Caribbean heroes and freedom fighters during slavery such as the Haitians, Mackandal or Toussaint Louverture, the Jamaican, Cudjoe or the Cuban Coba. Enslaved Africans who rebelled against oppression and fled from the plantation system are called maroons and their act, marronage. Except for Queen Nanny of the Jamaican Blue Mountains, only male names have been consecrated as maroons. Yet, enslaved women did fight against slavery and practice marronage. Caribbean writers have made a point of bringing to memory forgotten acts of marronage by women during slavery or shortly thereafter. This course proposes to examine the fictional treatment French-speaking Caribbean authors grant to African or Afro-descent women who historically rebelled against slavery and colonization. The literary works will be studied against the backdrop of “douboutism”, a conceptual framework derived from the common perception about women in the French Caribbean as expressed in the Creole say “fanm doubout” which means “strong woman”. Authors studied may include Suzanne Dracius (Martinique), Fabienne Kanor (Martinique), André Schwart-Bart (Guadeloupe), Maryse Condé (Guadeloupe), Evelyn Trouillot (Haiti). Conducted in French.

                                      • Class Comment

                                      • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                        166100
                                      • Bowdoin Bookstore
                                      • Registration Instructions
                                      AFRS 3301
                                      20006
                                      Senior Seminar in Africana Studies
                                      cHumanities                                       		M 6:30-9:25 PM Olufemi Vaughan TBA
                                       

                                      • Associated Term

                                        Spring 2014

                                      • Credits

                                        1.0

                                      • Separate Lab(s)

                                        No

                                      • Originating Department

                                        Africana Studies

                                        • Other Class Attributes

                                        Class Eligibility Rules

                                        • Permission Required

                                        • Major/Minor Restriction

                                        • Class Standing Restrictions

                                          Must NOT have one of the following Class Standings --

                                          First Year, First Semester

                                        • Class Exclusion

                                        • Prerequisite

                                          Two courses: (AFRS 1101 or 101) AND (AFRS 2000-2969 or 200-289)

                                        • Co-requisite

                                        • Equivalent Course(s)

                                          AFRS 301 From Spring 2011 Through Spring 2013

                                        • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                          1-senior majors/minors

                                          2-junior majors/minors

                                          3-senior non-majors/minors

                                          4-junior non-majors/minors

                                          5-sophomores

                                        • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                        • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                          No

                                        • Course Description

                                          Students conduct intensive research on a major topic in Africana studies that they have explored during the course of their academic experience in the Africana Studies Program. Students required to apply rigorous humanities and social science theories and concepts to African American, African, or African diaspora themes in the formation of their final research projects. Students required to give regular presentations of their research projects to Africana studies faculty and students.

                                        • Class Comment

                                        • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                          163130
                                        • Bowdoin Bookstore
                                        • Registration Instructions
                                        AFRS 3306
                                        20343
                                        The Common Good? A History of International Aid
                                        		 HIST 3360
                                        cHumanities                                         		T 1:00-3:55 PM David Gordon TBA
                                         

                                        • Associated Term

                                          Spring 2014

                                        • Credits

                                          1.0

                                        • Separate Lab(s)

                                          No

                                        • Originating Department

                                          History

                                          • Other Class Attributes

                                          Class Eligibility Rules

                                          • Permission Required

                                          • Major/Minor Restriction

                                          • Class Standing Restrictions

                                            Must NOT have one of the following Class Standings --

                                            First Year, First Semester

                                          • Class Exclusion

                                          • Prerequisite

                                            One of: (AFRS 1000-3999 or 010-399) OR (ASNS 1000-3999 or 010-399) OR (HIST 1000-3999 or 010-399) OR (LAS 1000-3999 or 010-399)

                                          • Co-requisite

                                          • Equivalent Course(s)

                                          • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                            All sophomores, juniors, and seniors equally

                                          • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                          • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                            No

                                          • Course Description

                                            The history of international aid to the “third world” through the twentieth century. Seminar considers the imperial mission and white man’s burden, aid during modern colonialism, the post-colonial aid community, the Bretton Woods Institutions, the rise of small-scale NGO aid interventions, aid in modern warfare, and the varied contemporary impacts of aid. Readings focus on Africa, along with examples from Latin America and South Asia. Participants should have some background in the history of at least one of these regions. Each student will write an original research paper on the history of an aid project.

                                          • Class Comment

                                          • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                            16880
                                          • Bowdoin Bookstore
                                          • Registration Instructions
                                          AFRS 3362
                                          20007
                                          Spiritual Encounters: African Religion in the Americas
                                          		 LAS 3362
                                          cHumanities                                           		TR 10:00-11:25 AM Laura Premack TBA
                                           

                                          • Associated Term

                                            Spring 2014

                                          • Credits

                                            1.0

                                          • Separate Lab(s)

                                            No

                                          • Originating Department

                                            Africana Studies

                                            • Other Class Attributes

                                            Class Eligibility Rules

                                            • Permission Required

                                            • Major/Minor Restriction

                                            • Class Standing Restrictions

                                              Must NOT have one of the following Class Standings --

                                              First Year, First Semester

                                            • Class Exclusion

                                            • Prerequisite

                                              One of: (AFRS 1000-3999 or 010-399) OR (LAS 1000-3999 or 010-399)

                                            • Co-requisite

                                            • Equivalent Course(s)

                                            • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                              1-majors/minors

                                              2-everyone else

                                            • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                            • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                              No

                                            • Course Description

                                              Investigates, historicizes, and theorizes how African, European, and indigenous beliefs about the spirit world have combined in the development of African diasporic religion in the Americas. Focuses particularly on Candomblé, Umbanda, and Spiritism in Brazil. Also considers Santerìa in Cuba, the Dominican Republic, and New York; Vodun in Haiti; Hoodoo in the Mississippi Delta; and Obeah in Jamaica and Guyana. Explores concepts of syncretism, hybridity, cultural encounter, identity, performance, and diaspora.

                                            • Class Comment

                                            • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                              162140
                                            • Bowdoin Bookstore
                                            • Registration Instructions
                                            AFRS 3600
                                            20035
                                            Race and Visual Representation in American Art
                                            		 ARTH 3600
                                            cHumanities                                             		MW 10:00-11:25 AM Dana Byrd TBA
                                             

                                            • Associated Term

                                              Spring 2014

                                            • Credits

                                              1.0

                                            • Separate Lab(s)

                                              No

                                            • Originating Department

                                              Art

                                              • Other Class Attributes

                                              Class Eligibility Rules

                                              • Permission Required

                                              • Major/Minor Restriction

                                              • Class Standing Restrictions

                                              • Class Exclusion

                                              • Prerequisite

                                                (ARTH 1100 or 100) OR (Placement above ARTH 1100)

                                              • Co-requisite

                                              • Equivalent Course(s)

                                              • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                                1-majors

                                                2-all other seniors and juniors

                                                3-sophomores

                                                4-first years

                                              • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                              • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                                No

                                              • Course Description

                                                Explores the visual construction of race in American art and culture from the colonial period to the late twentieth century. Focuses on two racial "categories"--blackness and whiteness--and how they have shaped American culture. Using college and local museum collections, examines paintings, sculptures, prints, photographs, film, and the spaces in which they have been displayed and viewed. Approach to this material is grounded in art history, but also draws from other disciplines. Artists under study include those who are well-known such as Homer and Walker as well as those who are unknown or have been forgotten.

                                              • Class Comment

                                              • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                                121020
                                              • Bowdoin Bookstore
                                              • Registration Instructions
                                              ANTH 1013
                                              20008
                                              Beyond Pocahontas: Native American Stereotypes
                                              bSocial & Behavioral Sciences                                               		TR 2:30-3:55 PM Kelly Fayard TBA
                                               

                                              • Associated Term

                                                Spring 2014

                                              • Credits

                                                1.0

                                              • Separate Lab(s)

                                                No

                                              • Originating Department

                                                Sociology and Anthropology

                                                • Other Class Attributes

                                                  Writing Project Course

                                                Class Eligibility Rules

                                                • Permission Required

                                                • Major/Minor Restriction

                                                • Class Standing Restrictions

                                                  Must have one of the following Class Standings --

                                                  First Year, First Semester

                                                • Class Exclusion

                                                • Prerequisite

                                                • Co-requisite

                                                • Equivalent Course(s)

                                                  ANTH 013 From Fall 2012 Through Fall 2012

                                                • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                                  First years only

                                                • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                                • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                                  No

                                                • Course Description

                                                  Traces the development of Native American stereotypes perpetuated by popular media both historically and presently. Considers effects of such stereotypes in contemporary media and popular culture. Analyzes films, literature, advertisements, cartoons, newspapers, magazines, and sports team mascots, among other forms of popular media and culture. Explores the diversity and variety of Native American peoples that are in opposition to media produced stereotypical images.

                                                • Class Comment

                                                • Bowdoin Bookstore
                                                • Registration Instructions
                                                ANTH 1101
                                                20009
                                                Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
                                                bSocial & Behavioral Sciences                                                 		TR 8:30-9:55 AM Greg Beckett TBA
                                                 

                                                • Associated Term

                                                  Spring 2014

                                                • Credits

                                                  1.0

                                                • Separate Lab(s)

                                                  No

                                                • Originating Department

                                                  Sociology and Anthropology

                                                  • Other Class Attributes

                                                  Class Eligibility Rules

                                                  • Permission Required

                                                  • Major/Minor Restriction

                                                  • Class Standing Restrictions

                                                  • Class Exclusion

                                                  • Prerequisite

                                                  • Co-requisite

                                                  • Equivalent Course(s)

                                                    ANTH 101 From Spring 1988 Through Spring 2013

                                                  • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                                    1-majors/minors

                                                    2-first years and sophomores

                                                    3-jr/sr non-minors

                                                  • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                                  • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                                    Yes

                                                  • Course Description

                                                    Cultural anthropology explores the diversities and commonalities of cultures and societies in an increasingly interconnected world. Introduces students to the significant issues, concepts, theories, and methods in cultural anthropology. Topics may include cultural relativism and ethnocentrism, fieldwork and ethics, symbolism, language, religion and ritual, political and economic systems, family and kinship, gender, class, ethnicity and race, nationalism and transnationalism, and ethnographic representation and validity.

                                                  • Class Comment

                                                  • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                                    5035150
                                                  • Bowdoin Bookstore
                                                  • Registration Instructions
                                                  ANTH 1102
                                                  20010
                                                  Introduction to Archaeology
                                                  bSocial & Behavioral Sciences                                                   		TR 10:00-11:25 AM Scott MacEachern TBA
                                                   

                                                  • Associated Term

                                                    Spring 2014

                                                  • Credits

                                                    1.0

                                                  • Separate Lab(s)

                                                    No

                                                  • Originating Department

                                                    Sociology and Anthropology

                                                    • Other Class Attributes

                                                    Class Eligibility Rules

                                                    • Permission Required

                                                    • Major/Minor Restriction

                                                    • Class Standing Restrictions

                                                    • Class Exclusion

                                                    • Prerequisite

                                                    • Co-requisite

                                                    • Equivalent Course(s)

                                                    • Registration Preferences for Spring Term

                                                      1-senior majors/minors

                                                      2-junior majors/minors

                                                      3-everyone else

                                                    • Registration Preferences for Fall Term

                                                    • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                                      Yes

                                                    • Course Description

                                                      An introduction to the practice of archaeology as the study of the human past. Introduces students to the methods and theories through which archaeologists use material traces to analyze the behaviors of people, from our earliest tool-making ancestors to the 20th century. Topics covered will include the history of archaeology as a professional discipline, the role of theory in archaeological interpretation, and the archaeological examination of ancient economic, social and ideological systems. Three well-known archaeological field projects will be used as source material for the course.

                                                    • Class Comment

                                                    • CapacityActualRemainingPending Requests
                                                      5032180
                                                    • Bowdoin Bookstore

                                                    Anthropological Research
                                                    bSocial & Behavioral Sciences                                                     		TR 11:30-12:55 PM Krista Van Vleet TBA

                                                      • Registration Priority for Previously Shut Out

                                                        Yes

                                                      • Course Description

                                                        Anthropological research methods and perspectives are examined through classic and recent ethnography, statistics and computer literacy, and the student’s own fieldwork experience. Topics include ethics, analytical and methodological techniques, the interpretation of data, and the use and misuse of anthropology.
